John Erskine (October 5, 1879 – June 2, 1951) was an American educator and author, pianist and composer.
John Erskine (October 5, 1879 – June 2, 1951) was an American educator and author, pianist and composer.
He was an English professor at Amherst College from 1903 to 1909, followed by Columbia University from 1909 to 1937.

In 1910, he led foundation of the Boar's Head Society for literature.

In 1920, he instituted Columbia College's General Honors Course, a two-year undergraduate seminar that would later help inspire "Masterworks of Western Literature," now known commonly as "Literature Humanities," the second component of Columbia College's Core Curriculum.
He found little support for the course from the senior faculty, and junior faculty members like Mark Van Doren and later after 1923, Mortimer Adler took up sections of the course.
The course was discontinued in 1928, though later reconstituted.
In 1929, Adler left Columbia to join University of Chicago, where he continued to work on the theme with Robert Hutchins, President of the university.

Together they subsequently went on to found the Great Books of the Western World program and the Great Books Foundation.Erskine co-wrote the 1900 Varsity Show at Columbia, writing the musical score for The Governor's Vrouw (1900), a two-act comic opera by Henry Sydnor Harrison and poet Melville Cane, who also wrote the lyrics.
